Award.AwardTitle: GOALI: In Situ Electron Microscopy Studies of Zinc Electrodeposition for Secondary Battery Applications
Award.AbstractNarration:
This IBM-UCLA-LLNL collaborative research aims to develop a fundamental understanding of the kinetics of nucleation, growth, and stability of electrodeposited zinc (Zn) thin films for applications in batteries. Rechargeable batteries, starting with lead-acid batteries, have been integral part of our society. With the surge in consumer electronics along with the recent demand for clean, sustainable energy, recyclable and rechargeable batteries have received renewed attention. Among the several possible candidate systems, zinc-alkaline and zinc-air batteries are attractive owing to their stability, safety, and cost. However, a major challenge impeding the realization of Zn-based rechargeable battery technology is the formation of high-aspect-ratio Zn dendrites and porous thin films, which reduce performance and operation life time. Progress in this area requires a basic understanding of the factors affecting the morphological evolution during electrodeposition at multiple length scales. This research addresses this issue via electrodeposition of zinc in situ in a transmission electron microscope and in situ in an optical microscope using Hele-Shaw cell geometries, which allow imaging of the interfacial structure during charge and discharge cycles. The acquisition of data as a function of solution chemistry and electrodepostion parameters enables the development of mechanistic insights into factors influencing the formation of smooth Zn thin films, an essential criterion for the realization of rechargeable batteries.

In addition to advancing knowledge important for the development of Zn-based rechargeable batteries, contributions to the society include training of future scientists and engineers with broader awareness of national laboratory and industrial research activities. This collaborative research provides to the postdoctoral scholars and students at UCLA opportunities for interactions with eminent scientists from industry (IBM) and national laboratory (LLNL), hands-on training on some of the most sophisticated state-of-the-art characterization tools, and exposure to industry's perspective on energy-related research.

POR.DRECONTENT:
GOALI: In Situ Electron Microscopy Studies of Zinc Electrodeposition for Secondary Battery Applications 

PI: Suneel Kodambaka (University of California Los Angeles)

Co-PIs: Christine Orme (Lawrence Livermore National Laboratory) and

Frances Ross (IBM T.J. Watson Research Laboratory)

 

This University-National Laboratory-Industry collaborative project focused on the determination of the mechanisms controlling growth front morphology during electrodeposition of Zn by imaging the evolution of the growth front under electrochemical conditions that mimic charge and discharge cycles in Zn-air batteries over length scales ranging from tens of nanometers up to hundreds of micrometers, using in situ transmission electron and optical microscopy techniques.

 During the course of this project, in situ electrochemical liquid-cell transmission electron microscopy (EC-TEM) was used to study zinc dendrite growth kinetics and the role of additives; in situ optical microscopy (OM) based electrochemical Hele-Shaw cell setup was developed for the studies of electrodeposition of zinc; in situ electrochemical atomic force microscopy (EC-AFM) measurements of the effects of pH and the nature of the substrate on surface roughness evolution during electrodeposition of zinc were also performed. Unexpected outcomes of these experiments include: in situ TEM studies of electrochemical corrosion of metals; investigation of the effects of electron beam irradiation on solution phase crystal growth; and the development of a novel pulsed electrochemical lithography, i.e. controlled electrochemical etching and deposition of metals, was developed. This potentially patentable technique is attractive for the large-scale fabrication of arrays of metal core-shell nanostructures of desired size and composition.

Broader Impacts: One undergraduate, one female doctoral student, and one post-doctoral scholar benefited from working on the state-of-the-art techniques (electrochemical AFM and TEM) with experts from LLNL and IBM. The outcomes of our research provide a deeper understanding of factors determining the performance of Zn-based battery technologies. The impact in understanding growth front evolution is expected to be relevant to electrochemical deposition in other materials, with applications spanning all length scales (micromechanical components, biomedical implants, up to heavy electrical power storage systems).

 To-date, one invited review article in Science, one paper in Nano Letters, and six extended abstracts as conference proceedings have been published. Six more manuscripts are in preparation and anticipated to be submitted before the end of the funding period. Seven contributed and nine invited talks have been presented. The graduated student theses will be available through UCLA library. The research publications are accessible online through the journal websites; PIs will provide electronic copies of the articles for those unable to access them.
